so in the rest of my talk i want to take you through what actually happens in your brain when you process code and
information in specific encode in specific i mean and then we'll see what that actually
means for your daily practice of programming so if information comes into your brain
through your eyes or through your ears it firstly enters the short term memory where it's stored for a very very brief
time this is like a little bit like an io buffer very small and stored very briefly
we've known this for a very long time actually george miller a researcher already in the 1950s described that your
short-term memory is very very limited very small and it might only be able to
hold between five and nine things at the same time so it's a very brief story it
is not something you can just clamp lots of information into and just to give you a
sense because i know just saying like five to nine elements is very very abstract so let's do a little experiment
i will show you a very brief sentence for a very short amount of time like half a second and then it's your goal to
remember this sentence i hope you're participating at home here we
go that was that was really hard right now you're like well this is this is impossible
i cannot process that information so this is the limitation of your short-term memory you look at this
information and even if i would have allowed you to study it a little bit longer you would not have been able to
really remember all the characters because your short term memory is so small
but i guess you also figured out that i only showed you part of the puzzle because well this these weren't real
letters right right it isn't just your short-term memory that does the process your
short-term memory takes the information that comes into your brain and sends it to the working memory in your working
memory you can see that a little bit like a processor in the brain it is processing information
your working memory works together collaborates with the long-term so your long-term memory is it's a bit like an
angel on your shoulder that when presented with information when information is in a working memory your
long-term memory will be like oh i know this information here's here's related information that also might be of value
to you so it's always trying to give you information that you already know to help you process the
information currently being processed to see this process in action we will do
another puzzle similar puzzle three words shown very briefly and it is your goal to remember
the sentence here we go so that was easy right it was still hard
but i guess it was easier and i guess also your little long-term memory angel was jumping on your shoulder i hope i

sentence was removed but something was happening right you were recognizing letters and you were
trying to make sentences out of the letters or words and then sentences this is because your long-term memory
was now activated because of recognizable stuff was shown to show the power of the long-term
memory for processing we will do one more memory exercise very similar three
words shown briefly here we go don't blink or you might miss it
so that was doable right that was probably relatively easy so you see
the more you know the more you can process
this catalyst cake for you it's relatively easy you just look at the words and immediately you grasp it

it's certainly not doing half a circle oh in a circle and a squiggly and a catholic cross and a stripe immediately

process so these chunks is what is called individual elements are retrieved from

you go like okay i see the individual parts but like how how do they work together it's
almost like you would want to take your finger it's going like oh well uh
i don't know let's let's put n is seven okay if n is seven then and the value by
2 this is 3 this is the string 1. right you cannot at once grasp the program you
have to do this step by step basically your mind wants to play the compiler to figure out what's going on
this is a working memory issue you have all the information you understand all the information but you're not able to
put it together so these different forms of confusion are important because
if you recognize what part of your brain is engaged too much is struggling with a
certain piece of code you also know how to solve it because each of these different forms of confusion have a
different solution and if you just pile them together as oh code reading is hard this is confusing i don't know what to
do then you don't know what to do whereas if you understand oh this code is hard
because this presents a long-term memory issue you also have a path towards being less confused
so for this type of code where we have a long-term memory issue the path to less confusion is to
practice to practice syntax and a nice strategy for that is flash cards in
which you make little paper cards a little bit like this like business cards
and then on one side you put the syntax element and on the other side you put the definition so if you are learning
apl you could say well this is a t it's actually not a t it is an encode symbol
you can practice but of course assuming most of you don't want to learn apl what you can also do is put python
on one side and java on the other and then train yourself in that or if you're
not necessarily struggling with a new programming language but with a new business domain you can also put domain
concepts on one side and the definition of the domain concepts on the other side
and you simply put this stack on your desk and every once in a while you take a card
and you're like do i know this domain concept ah let's see ah i do know this or you don't and then you practice again
and the book has a lot more strategies to practice but this is just something you can do to practice
so it's really important that if your long-term memory is suffering from confusion it doesn't make
sense to plow on it doesn't make sense if you're reading code in which half of the main concepts are unfamiliar to you
to think i will just read this again it will get it will not get better you really need
this familiarity it shouldn't cost you too much energy to process individual parts of the code otherwise you will not
continue and again think of how much easier it was to process catalyst cake
than the other two sentences don't let yourself be in such a situation
this code though has a spectacularly different type of solution if you're struggling with code that is of which
you know the individual elements but they are shaped in a form that aren't isn't so convenient to you what you can
do is rewrite the code so if you are maybe coming from java and you're not so
used to list comprehension you can rewrite this code this second code snippet does the exact same thing
as the top codes but might be depending on your prior knowledge way
more comfortable to you where you say oh i make an empty list and then what i do is i loop over this list customers for
every c i check are they older than 50 yes then i add their names to the list
and this is what i call in the book a cognitive refactoring it is a refactoring because you're not really
changing the behavior of the code it is the same code snippets but you're taking the code and you're moving it closer to
your own prior knowledge if you're not so familiar with list comprehension the second form is easier to use and of
course like this snippet isn't the code page right you must imagine that you're in a big method of which some list
comprehensions are part and that's just a waste of your time if for every list comprehension you
go like oh yeah oh what is this again that distracts you again from the bigger picture so you can rewrite parts of the
code to make it easier to process again the book has a lot more different
cognitive refactorings there are all sorts of other things you can do to massage the code to be more easily
processable for you some people now might be yelling angrily right at their screen saying this is not
a refactoring you're making the code worse so in some cases it is true that
you would want to roll back this code to its original form but if you have something like
a github repo of course you can just make your own branch do some refactoring there for comprehension
and throw away the branch later so in many cases this is not a refactoring you want to commit it's really refactoring
your use temporarily to gain a better understanding of code
finally then if you have code that is of this type where it's just really hard on the working memory you can support your
working memory you can use techniques many of them are described in the book that help your working memory where
you're like oh i i am processing too much data at once let me offload some of
this data onto a piece of paper or a whiteboard or even in your codes for
example just an example is to make a little state table in which you say okay i'm going to try to understand this code
for the value seven just say okay this is the the initialization phase okay now
this happens in the first loop this happens in the second loop and that can give you a better grasp of what the code
is actually doing so in summary in short if you understand
your own understanding and understand your own misunderstanding this will really make you a better programmer
because instead of just saying i am confused you can say my long-term memory
has too little prior knowledge i need to improve that so it will help you hopefully out of a situation in which
you feel confused and powerless and gives you techniques to help you out and to help you advance to more
understanding if you want to know more there's many things you can do one thing you can do
